awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Flow Cytometer Instrument at University of Michigan-Dearborn
awd_abstract_narration:
Flow cytometry/cell sorting is a high-throughput technique for doing high level qualitative and quantitative analysis on a per cell basis for large cell populations.  The acquisition of new flow cytometry equipment at the University of Michigan-Dearborn will facilitate research on tumor dynamics, glaucoma, pancreatic islets microfluidics, therapeutics to combat cancer, and brain injury and infection.  A strategy for wide sharing of the instrument among neighboring universities is included as part of this project.  The new instrument will help in developing the multidisciplinary undergraduate and graduate curriculum in bioengineering and the natural sciences. Furthermore, the instrument will provide opportunities to develop interesting science and engineering outreach activities that introduce bioengineering to high school students and teachers from the greater Detroit area.  Undergraduate summer research programs, such as the Research Experiences for Undergraduates program, will be built around the techniques of flow cytometry, which most undergraduate students can readily learn. 

The acquisition of a flow cytometer will substantially improve the quality and scope of bioengineering research at The University of Michigan-Dearborn.  Bioengineering research at the university spans diverse areas, including protein aggregation, engineering tumor models, biophysical characterization of cellular functions, mechanobiological pathways in the eye, transport mechanisms across the brain, nanoengineering, and islet microfluidics. The flow cytometer will enhance these research programs by furnishing information on the physical and chemical characteristics of particles/cell suspensions, cell populations, expression of cellular biomarkers, protein aggregation, and nanoparticle toxicity effects. The flow cytometer will provide the team of users, which includes six junior faculty, with a cutting-edge tool necessary to establish new research programs and to broaden collaborations with researchers at other institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The unavailability of a flow cytometer at the UM-Dearborn (UM-D) campus caused serious limitations in research and education in  biological, biochemistry, and biomaterial systems at UM-D campus. The acquisition of the flow cytometer has provided a flow based analytical capability of cells and particles for our on-campus research and education in bioengineering as well as chemistry, materials science, and biology.

The PI and co-PIs have incorporated Flow cytometer system in the existing undergraduate courses including Fundamentals of Drug delivery (BENG 426, BENG 526), and Biotransport (BENG 425), or in the process of incorporating in the existing undergraduate Biosensors and Bioelectronics (BENG 351), and Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering (BENG 375). The Mechanical Engineering Department has recently introduced new Graduate programs (MSc in Bioengineering and PhD in Mechanical Sciences and Engineering, which includes a bioengineering track). Flow cytometer will be also incorporated in the graduate courses including Molecular and Cell Biology (BENG 520) and Bioengineering Research (BENG 600).

The PI, Co-PIs, and other users have been integrating the Flow cytometer to expand their existing research focus in protein aggregation, nanotheranostics, tissue engineering, cancer biology, diabetes research, as well as research in glaucoma. The results have been disseminated via journal publication, and two Masters Thesis.

In addition to training provided to the undergraduate students as a part of the laboratory component of the Bioengineering courses, the PI and Co-PIs have recruited many undergraduate and graduate students (majority of them are women) for conducting research with them. These students are trained on the use of flow cytometer regularly as a part of their research/projects. Additionally, the PI, co-PIs, and the users of the flow cytometer participate in UM-Dearborn's STEM outreach activities. As a part of this activity, the PIs are involved in organizing educational activities for middle and high school students. Demo sessions and hands-on exposure to the flow cytometer will be organized to encourage students to pursue career in STEM fields.

In summary, the flow cytometer is helping in strengthening the research infrastructure at UM-D campus, improving the research as well as educational objectives of the students, as well as encouraging the high school students to pursue career in STEM fields and broadening the participation of underprivileged/underrepresented groups.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Mathumai Kanapathipillai
